Graphical abstract This review summarizes the main problems existing in all-solid-state batteries (ASSBs) at the present stage, the challenges faced by high-voltage all-solid-state electrolytes, the improvement strategies, and the prospect of the future, aiming to provide research direction for the development of high-voltage ASSBs. Solid-state batteries (SSBs) are highly attractive on account of their high energy density and good safety. In high-voltage and high-current conditions, however, the interface reactions, structural changes, and decomposition of the electrolyte impede the transmission of lithium ions in all-solid-state lithium batteries (ASSLBs), significantly reducing the charging and discharging capacity and cycling stability of the battery and therefore restricting its practical applications. The main content of review is to conduct an in-depth analysis of the existing problems of solid-state batteries from the aspects of interface reactions, material failure, ion migration, and dendrite growth, and points out the main factors influencing the electrochemical performance of ASSLBs. Additionally, the compatibility and ion conduction mechanisms between polymer electrolytes, inorganic solid electrolytes, and composite electrolytes and the electrode materials are discussed. Furthermore, the perspectives of electrode materials, electrolyte properties, and interface modification are summarized and prospected, providing new optimization directions for the future commercialization of high-voltage solid-state electrolytes. Keywords All-solid-state batteries Solid-state electrolytes High-voltage electrolytes Interface compatibility Ionic conduction 1 Introduction In response to the rapidly increasing demands of social and economic development, there is an urgent need to develop stable, reliable, and renewable technologies for power generation and storage. Lithium-ion batteries present substantial potential for various practical applications, attributable to their high energy density and compact form factor. Lithium metal, as an anode material, stands out for its low electrochemical potential (−3.04 V vs. the standard hydrogen electrode) and exceptionally high specific capacity (3860 mAh/g) [1,2]. These properties position lithium metal as a leading contender for next-generation high-energy-density secondary batteries. While liquid lithium-ion battery systems offer high ionic conductivity and excellent interfacial wetting, their use of lithium metal is hindered by significant challenges. These include high reactivity with organic liquid electrolytes, instability under extreme conditions, and safety risks associated with dendrite formation during cycling. Solid-state electrolytes (SSEs) are emerging as one of most promising solutions to address the challenges associated with lithium metal anodes. Replacing liquid electrolytes with solid-state materials not only improves the electrochemical performance and safety of batteries but also reduces the reliance on separator materials, thereby lowering raw material costs. Additionally, SSEs used in lithium-ion batteries are primarily categorized into two types: lithium-ion conducting polymers and inorganic lithium-ion conducting ceramics. Fig. 1 compares the advantages and disadvantages of polymer, inorganic, and composite electrolytes with liquid electrolytes simply. But no matter for which type of solid electrolyte, high voltage performance has always been a short board. For lithium-ion batteries, broadening the battery operating voltage range is one of the important ways to improve energy density. In the traditional liquid battery system, a series of interface reactions such as electrolyte oxidation and decomposition are easy to occur under the condition of high voltage (4.2–4.3 V), resulting in a sharp decline in battery performance. In contrast, the solid electrolyte has better high voltage stability, greatly reducing the occurrence of side reactions at the interface, and the charging voltage can reach about 4.6 V, so that it can work under a higher voltage platform, and the battery energy density has been significantly improved [3]. At the same time, because of its solid nature, the solid electrolyte will not leak during use, nor will it produce a lot of heat and gas as the liquid electrolyte under high voltage due to oxidation reaction. In the application scenarios such as electric vehicles with high safety requirements, the high voltage solid electrolyte can greatly reduce the safety risk caused by battery failure. In addition, the use of high-pressure solid electrolytes is not affected by the extreme external environment, and the capacity retention rate during the cycle is much higher than that of liquid electrolytes, providing a safe and reliable energy supply for the aerospace field and some satellite equipment. Therefore, most scholars have carried out a series of related research work. In the polymer solid electrolyte system, as a typical polymer electrolyte, polyethylene oxide (PEO) was initially employed for the fabrication of solid electrolytes (SEs) due to its high solubility of lithium salts and ability to conduct lithium ions. However, PEO-based electrolytes exhibit several limitations, including a narrow operating voltage window, poor high-temperature stability, and low mechanical strength, necessitating the incorporation of other polymers, plasticizers, and inorganic fillers to enhance their voltage resistance. These challenges have necessitated the incorporation of secondary materials, including other polymers, plasticizers, and inorganic fillers, to enhance their electrochemical performance. Inorganic fillers are categorized as active (e.g., Li3N, LiAlO2) and inactive (e.g., Al2O3, SiO2, MgO) fillers based on their roles in ion conduction [4]. Efforts to improve polymer-based SEs have yielded materials like acrylonitrile (PAN) [5,6], poly (methyl methacrylate) (PMMA) [7,8], and poly (vinylidene fluoride) (PVDF) [9]. Despite the improvements made in enhancing the mechanical strength of polymer SEs, their inherent drawbacks remain evident as previously outlined [10]. A feasible strategy to overcome these challenges involves combining polymers with lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide LiTFSI [11], inorganic fillers [12], plasticizers [13], and other polymers [14] to reduce crystallinity, enhance ionic conductivity, and broaden the voltage window. Furthermore, techniques such as electrospinning have been employed to fabricate grid-like interlayer [15] or “sandwich” composite structures, significantly improving the mechanical strength of polymer electrolytes. A room-temperature tensile strength of 31.73 MPa has been achieved, approximately 30 times higher than that of conventional polymer electrolytes (1–5 MPa), effectively suppressing lithium dendrite growth [16]. Despite these improvements, polymer SEs still face challenges, the shortcomings of low ionic conductivity, high voltage easy oxidation, and poor mechanical strength are still obvious, although the high voltage stability and mechanical strength of polymer based solid electrolytes have been improved after a series of modification treatments. However, in the long-term cycle of the battery, the oxidation reaction will still lead to the gradual degradation of the polymer-based solid electrolyte, which will aggravate the phenomenon of lithium dendrite penetration, cause the battery short circuit, and greatly reduce the electrochemical cycle performance of the solid state battery [17]. Inorganic SEs offer a compelling alternative due to their superior ionic conductivity and mechanical robustness. These materials are categorized into oxides, hydrides, and sulfides, with ionic conductivities ranging from 10−5 to 10−3 S/cm, comparable to or exceeding those of liquid electrolytes. For example, perovskite-type electrolytes (Li3 x La2/3− x TiO3) exhibit room-temperature ionic conductivities of up to 10−3 S/cm [18]. NASICON-type electrolytes (Li1+ x M x Ti2− x (PO4)3, where M = Al, Cr, Ga, Fe, Sc, In, Lu, Y, or La) offer good stability at room temperature and are typically used in hybrid batteries or as additives for polymer electrolytes. Garnet-type electrolytes, such as Li7La3Zr2O12 (LLZO) [19] and Li7− x La3Zr2− x Ta x O2 (LLZTO, x = 0–2) [20], also show promise, but their ionic conductivity remains inferior to that of sulfide electrolytes. Hydride SEs, including LiBH4 and Mg(BH4)2, exhibit high ionic conductivities (10−3 S/cm) and stability with lithium metal, making them promising candidates for future applications [21]. Sulfide-based SEs, such as Li2S-P2S5 glass ceramics, LGPS-type electrolytes, and Li6PS5X sulfides, exhibit the highest ionic conductivities reported to date but face challenges related to their reactivity with lithium metal. For instance, Li10GeP2S12 interacts with lithium to form conductive byproducts, increasing interface resistance and accelerating degradation [22]. Strategies to address these challenges include using lithium-indium alloy anodes or introducing stable interfacial layers to mitigate decomposition. In the liquid lithium battery system, the organic liquid electrolyte exhibits excellent infiltration into the positive and negative electrode materials, as shown in Fig. 2 (a). Li+ ions are transported via anionic interactions between the liquid electrolytes, resulting in a discharge process with two distinct reaction stages. For polymer-based electrolytes, Li+ ions move through the polymer matrix via segmental motion and interactions with anions, producing a discharge curve similar to liquid electrolytes due to solid-liquid interfacial reactions (Fig. 2b). For inorganic solid electrolytes, the electrolyte and the positive and negative electrode materials are interfaced through solid-solid contacts. During discharge, Li+ ions travel through the bulk material and grain boundaries, leading to a single discharge platform at 2.0 V (Fig. 2c) [23]. Compared with polymer solid electrolyte, inorganic solid electrolyte has relatively high chemical stability, ionic conductivity, and mechanical strength, but the high interface resistance caused by solid-solid interface contact between electrolyte and electrode plate leads to local overheating at the interface at high voltage and large current, causing a series of electrochemical reactions. The growth of lithium dendrites and the decomposition of solid electrolyte are aggravated, and the cycle stability of the battery is sharply decreased. In order to achieve the target energy density of 500 Wh/kg for all-solid-state lithium-ion batteries, the development of high-voltage solid-state electrolytes is particularly important [24]. Table 1 lists the basic electrochemical characteristics of several common solid electrolytes [10,11,21,25–36]. Polymer electrolytes offer good bonding and compatibility with electrode materials but suffer from a narrow voltage window. The inorganic solid electrolyte exhibits high ionic conductivity and a broader voltage window but faces significant challenges in interfacial contact and stability with electrodes. These challenges highlight the importance of developing solid electrolytes with a balance of high electrochemical stability, mechanical strength, and compatibility with both electrodes to enable high-voltage solid-state batteries. This paper provides an analysis of the impacts of conductivity, mechanical strength, and interface stability on the performance of solid-state batteries. The study delves into the roles of the positive and negative electrodes, electrode-electrolyte interfaces, and the solid electrolyte structure, while also exploring the future direction of high-voltage solid-state electrolyte development. 2 The failure mechanisms of high-voltage solid-state batteries 2.1 Failure of the interface Compared to liquid lithium-ion batteries, solid-state lithium batteries promise higher energy density and enhanced safety, making them highly desirable for advanced technologies. Nonetheless, interface-related issues remain a major obstacle to their widespread application. Unlike liquid electrolytes, SSEs are uniform, solid thin films that lack favorable wetting properties with electrode materials. Their poor wetting properties hinder effective contact with electrode materials, impeding lithium-ion transport and reducing battery efficiency. Ceramic SSEs require compression into thin sheets before assembly with lithium-indium and powdered electrodes. Insufficient pressure leads to poor interface contact and high resistance, while excessive pressure can deform the lithium-indium electrode, exacerbate dendrite growth, and disrupt electrolyte integrity [37]. Furthermore, interface issues within the solid electrolyte material, such as poor contact between phases or particles, can lead to low ionic conductivity and limit the power density [38]. Under high voltage conditions, the interface between the solid electrolyte and the electrodes may degrade the electrolyte or decompose electrode materials, which increases interface resistance. In extreme cases, such side reactions can generate gas and heat, leading to rapid kinetic reactions that may expand the interface, induce thermal runaway phenomena, and potentially cause open flames in the battery [39]. Addressing these challenges requires interfaces with high ionic conductivity and electronic insulation, facilitating efficient lithium-ion transport while preventing side reactions at the electrolyte-anode boundary. 2.2 Failure of materials Material failure at the solid electrolyte interface represents a critical bottleneck in the advancement of all-solid-state batteries (ASSBs). Unlike liquid-based batteries, ASSBs depend on rigid solid-solid interfaces, where any compromise in structural integrity can cascade into severe performance degradation. The collapse of electrode structures, particularly at the interface, is a key failure mode that undermines the mechanical and electrochemical stability of these systems. During cycling, electrode structure collapse can result in lithium-ion loss, capacity decay, and delamination from the current collector (Fig. 3 a, b), which ultimately contributes to a sharp decline in capacity. For the typical LiNi x Mn y Co(1− x − y )O2 (NMC) cathode material, the volume change of the active substance during the charge and discharge cycle is 6%–8% [40], not only resulting in gaps of the contact of solid particles in the composite cathode material and the hindered ion and electron migration, but also leading to incomplete contact between the composite cathode and the solid electrolyte, resulting in increased interface resistance or interface stress forcing the solid electrolyte to produce micro-cracks, thus affecting the battery performance. How to further improve the interface contact between electrode and solid electrolyte and reduce the mechanical stress and interface resistance is the main problem faced by all-solid-state batteries. For example, the interface reaction between the common LAGP electrolyte and the lithium metal negative electrode involves amorphous and volume expansion. The higher the voltage, the higher the current density, and the greater the non-uniformity of the interface [41]. An electrode-electrolyte contact interface with good electrochemical stability and a high voltage stable solid electrolyte are necessary conditions for the development of all-solid-state batteries. The rigid and brittle nature of SEs places significant stress on electrode materials during the assembly process of all-solid-state batteries (ASSBs). This mechanical stress leads to microstructural damage, exacerbating the degradation of the electrodes and ultimately hindering battery performance. To mitigate these effects, SEs with a low elastic modulus are highly desirable for ASSBs. The flexibility and ductility of both the solid electrolyte and the electrodes significantly influence the interface contact. A low-modulus solid electrolyte exhibits desirable flexibility, preventing breakage due to external mechanical stresses during battery assembly while ensuring a favorable contact area. This configuration avoids point-to-point contact at the solid-solid interface, thereby reducing interface resistance. Moreover, adequate flexibility substantially inhibits the growth of lithium dendrites during cycling, thereby mitigating the risk of short circuits caused by structural failure of the solid electrolyte. Tippens et al. utilized in situ X-ray computed tomography (CT) visualization techniques to investigate the fracture and interphase growth processes of the Li1+ x Al x Ge2− x (PO4)3 (LAGP) solid electrolyte in a symmetric solid-state battery throughout its cycling. Their observations revealed the emergence of significant cracks at the interface following cycling. As the current density increased, the area of crack propagation was expanded, leading to a marked increase in impedance (Fig. 3c). However, the impedance did not increase significantly before the crack initiation, and the generation of ion-electron interface phase did not hinder ion or electron transport. With the increase of current density, the crack expansion area gradually increased, and the impedance increased sharply, indicating that the electrochemical failure of the battery was due to mechanical fracture, which hindered the Li+ ion transport. Ion transport may be affected by an increase in the number of cracks as well as an increase in the volume of the void fracture area, resulting in contact loss. Through finite element simulations, they demonstrated that the interface layer between the electrolyte and the electrode serves as a source of cracking during cycling (Fig. 3d–h). The concentration of mechanical stress at this interface contributes to the degradation of the electrolyte, which is a principal factor in the increased battery impedance, ultimately leading to short-circuiting [42]. 2.3 Ion migration and dendrite growth The lithium metal anode, celebrated for its low electrochemical potential, high theoretical specific capacity, and ease of processing, remains the ideal candidate for all-solid-state lithium batteries (ASSLBs). However, its performance is significantly hindered by the uneven growth of lithium dendrites during battery cycling. Although SEs with low elastic moduli offer excellent compatibility with both electrodes and successfully reduce interface resistance, they often fail to restrain dendrite formation effectively. Once initiated, these dendrites exploit the weaker regions of the solid electrolyte, progressively propagating until they breach the structure and induce a short circuit. Conversely, SEs with a high modulus exhibit increased hardness, which can inhibit the surface dendrite growth of lithium metal during cycling. However, this enhancement in dendrite suppression comes at the cost of diminished interface compatibility with the electrode materials, leading to a marked increase in interface resistance. The formation of lithium dendrites primarily occurs in three morphologies: moss-like, tree-like, and granular. Despite these variations in appearance, the underlying mechanisms governing their formation and growth are similar. Initial nucleation sites dictate lithium deposition, where larger protrusions generate a higher electric field, attracting more lithium ions to tips and accelerating dendritic growth. Shen et al. conducted in-situ X-ray tomography on slices of LLZO SEs at high beam energies (>40 eV) across various temperatures. They revealed that the diffusion dynamics of lithium ions along grain boundaries significantly influence dendrite formation and short-circuiting. The porous structure and uneven surface of the solid electrolyte affect lithium dendrite growth [43], demonstrating that even in solid-state configurations, uneven deposition of lithium can lead to short-circuiting. The growth mechanism of lithium dendrites in solid-state batteries also differs markedly from that in liquid-state batteries. In liquid batteries, the liquid electrolyte is intimately connected to the lithium metal, allowing for a uniform lithium-ion flux and deposition across various sites. In contrast, solid-state batteries suffer from poor physical contact at the electrode interface due to the presence of grain boundaries and pores, leading to lithium deposition in areas lacking sufficient Li+ conduction pathways, resulting in vertically growing dendrites. Applied stress in SSBs further aggravates this process, directing dendrite growth along structural voids and grain boundaries. This leads to fractures in the electrolyte, undermining cycle life and battery stability [44]. Additionally, under high-voltage conditions, uneven ion migration can cause localized overheating. These hot spots facilitate dendrite formation in interface voids, perpetuating a cycle of thermal instability and structural failure. Such deposition leads to localized overheating at critical contact points under high current conditions, creating a vicious cycle that culminates in battery short-circuiting. Experimental studies on various ceramic-based solid electrolyte materials have indicated that lithium dendrites preferentially initiate on the surfaces of electrolyte particles [45]. Nagao et al. investigated the morphology of lithium deposition and dissolution on the lithium anode of a sulfide solid-state battery before and after cycling using in situ microscopy. As illustrated in Fig. 4 (a–d), lithium deposition resulted in the emergence of multiple microcracks near the interface between the solid electrolyte and the electrode, which was gradually expanded. Initially, lithium metal was deposited in the voids of the solid sulfide electrolyte and subsequently grew along the solid electrolyte toward the collector electrode, as depicted in Fig. 4(e–h). The formation of these cracks is likely attributed to the localized stress resulting from dendrite growth, ultimately leading to short-circuiting in the solid-state battery [46]. Therefore, it is essential to develop SSEs with high ionic conductivity and pressure resistance, coupled with rational interface coatings to reduce interface resistance in fully operational solid-state batteries. 2.4 Electrolyte degradation As a key component of solid-state batteries, the physical and electrochemical characteristics of the electrolytes directly affect the charge-discharge capacity, rate performance, and cycle performance of all-solid-state batteries. Solid electrolytes are usually required to have high ionic conductivity, wide voltage stability window, good mechanical properties, good chemical stability with electrodes, excellent thermal stability, simple manufacturing process, low cost, and environmental friendliness. Commonly used solid electrolyte materials are roughly divided into two categories. The one is an inorganic solid electrolyte, and the other is a polymer based composite solid electrolyte. No matter what type of solid electrolyte, its scope of application has a big problem. For high-voltage all-solid-state batteries, in order to obtain a high specific discharge capacity, the electrolyte material must be required to remain stable at a high cut-off voltage, but most solid electrolytes decompose at a high cut-off voltage. The charge and discharge process of the battery is also a dynamic cycle process, accompanied by ion migration inside the battery and electron migration outside the battery, a series of side reactions will occur inside the battery, including chemical side reactions between the electrolyte and the electrode, redox degradation of the electrolyte itself by inserting or removing electrons or ionophore, and electrochemical reactions [47]. For example, the common sulfide solid electrolyte LGPS begins to delithium and oxidize at 2.14 V, and forms three final products of P2S5, GeS2, and S at the equilibrium oxidation potential of 2.31 V. Similar sulfides such as L3PS4, Li4GeS4, and Li7P3S11 will be oxidized to form S elemental at 2–2.5 V. The oxidation stability potential of NASICON electrolyte materials such as LATP and LAGP is slightly higher, reaching about 4.2 V [48]. The oxide solid electrolyte has a higher oxidation potential than the sulfide, and the oxidation of LLZO, LISICON, and LLTO starts at 2.91, 3.39, and 3.71 V, respectively, while the oxidation potential will be lower for most polymer electrolytes. At the same time, the interface between the solid-state electrolyte and the positive electrode requires extremely high compatibility, because the high-voltage positive electrode material has relatively high oxidizability in the high delithium state, which constantly reacts with the solid-state electrolyte to form a chemically unstable interfacial layer, hindering Li+ transport and causing electron leakage, resulting in a sharp decline in the performance of the solid-state battery [49,50]. Most studies have shown that in order to further improve the high voltage stability of solid electrolyte materials, its modification mainly focuses on enhancing ionic conductivity and solving interface problems, such as LiNiO3 coating, high electrochemical stability of polymer electrolytes, and interface addition, because their low voltage stability window makes it difficult to match high voltage cathodes, resulting in structural degradation of electrolyte materials [47]. 3 Designing strategies for high-voltage solid-state batteries Insights into failure mechanisms reveal that material design is a foundational step in developing high-voltage solid-state batteries. To achieve exceptional electrochemical performance, it is essential to synthesize solid electrolytes (SEs) with high ionic conductivity [51]. Unlike the ion transport mechanism in liquid electrolytes, where dissolved lithium salts form solvated ions in high-dielectric solvents and migrate under the influence of a potential gradient, solid-state batteries rely on crystalline defects to enable lithium transport. In solid electrolytes, ion diffusion occurs along energetically favorable paths provided by point defects such as vacancies, interstitial atoms, Frenkel defects, and Schottky defects. These point defects govern the type and concentration of charge carriers within the solid electrolyte. Lithium-ion migration typically proceeds via a single-atom hopping mechanism, which can be categorized into three modes: (1) direct hopping of interstitial atoms between adjacent sites, (2) a knock-on mechanism involving interstitial atoms, and (3) vacancy-assisted direct hopping (Fig. 5 c) [52,53]. For instance, in sulfide-based SEs, lithium ions preferentially occupy tetrahedral sites within the face-centered cubic S2− lattice, migrating along pathways that connect co-planar tetrahedral sites with minimal energy barriers (Fig. 5b). Notably, migration barriers are significantly higher in cubic and hexagonal close-packed structures (Fig. 5d, e), highlighting the influence of structural configurations on ionic transport. These insights emphasize the need to optimize ion migration pathways in the design process [54]. In addition to optimizing ionic conductivity, the effects of cathode and anode materials, as well as the electrolyte-electrode interface, must be carefully considered during the design of solid-state batteries. In solid-state lithium metal batteries, lithium metal is a promising anode material. However, its high reactivity with most solid electrolytes often results in contamination of the anode through lithium incorporation, necessitating strict control over side reactions. Similarly, for cathode materials, compositional adjustments via doping and coating techniques have been shown to mitigate side reactions, thereby enhancing structural stability [55–58]. The electrolyte-electrode interface is another pivotal factor in material design. Interface challenges manifest primarily in two ways. First, the solid-solid contact between the electrolyte and electrode is often incomplete, characterized by point-to-point contact. This increases interfacial resistance and hinders lithium-ion transport, potentially leading to localized overheating and promoting dendrite growth [59]. Second, reactive interactions between the electrode and electrolyte result in the formation of interfacial layers during prolonged cycling. This phenomenon gradually decomposes the electrolyte material, ultimately degrading battery performance [60]. Collectively, these challenges highlight the complexity and significance of material design in advancing solid-state battery technology. 3.1 High voltage resistant solid electrolyte 3.1.1 Polymeric electrolyte Polymers, as macromolecules formed through covalent bonding of repeating monomer units, are known for their high melting points, chemical stability, and dimensional resilience. In solid-state electrolytes, polymers are required to demonstrate flexibility, elasticity, and wettability, promoting excellent interfacial contact with electrodes and reducing resistance. Polymer electrolytes combine a polymer matrix with lithium salts, where the solubility of the salts is key. Lithium salt incorporation lowers the matrix’s crystallinity, generating amorphous regions conducive to ion transport, while enhancing lithium-ion mobility, ultimately improving the ionic conductivity of the electrolyte. The performance of solid polymer electrolytes was primarily evaluated through their ionic conductivity and cation transference number. A low lithium-ion transference number indicates that only a limited fraction of the total current is carried by cations, signifying reduced efficiency of Li+ transport across the electrolyte compared to the anionic groups of the salt. This diminished cation transference adversely impacts battery performance, as the migration rate of lithium ions directly affects the polarization of the negatively charged salt carriers, thereby limiting the ability of the battery to sustain rapid charge and discharge cycles. In polymer electrolyte systems (Fig. 6 a), Li+ transport relies on segmental motion within the polymer chains. As the concentration of lithium salts and inorganic fillers increases (Fig. 6b, c), ionic conduction is enhanced through interactions between anions, polymer chain segments, and the incorporated inorganic fillers, further boosting ionic conductivity. The polymer substrates most extensively studied include polyethylene oxide (PEO), polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF), and cross-linked composite materials of various polymers. PEO contains low polyether (–CH2–CH2O–) n groups, which dissolve lithium ions when blended with alkali metal salts, forming a conductive electrolyte with a relatively low glass transition temperature (T g) of −67 °C. The room-temperature ionic conductivity of pure PEO is only 10−6–10−8 S/cm, and its narrow electrochemical window makes it unsuitable for application in ASSBs. To improve the electrochemical performance of PEO, selecting an appropriate lithium salt concentration is essential. Lithium ions can migrate through the vibration of the –C–O–C– chain segment, and are affected by the degree of microscopic regional disorder of polymer-based materials. The conductivity, mechanical properties, and thermal stability of lithium ions in pure PEO electrolytes are quite poor. The addition of functional fillers to the polymer can optimize the multi-scale interactions and conductive interfaces within the polymer, thereby improving the overall properties of the polymer. For example, Hu et al. demonstrated that adding LiTFSI and mesoporous α-AlF3 nanoparticles (HS-AlF3), PEO has a high degree of dissociation to LiTFSI, while HS-AlF3 can accelerate the dissociation of adjacent lithium base salts and enhance the overall transmission rate of lithium ions. Moreover, the addition of fluoride can also reduce the polarization phenomenon and stabilize the electrode interface. By inhibiting the growth of lithium dendrite and extending the cathode voltage range, the voltage stability window of the composite solid electrolyte is as high as 4.9 V, and the ionic conductivity at room temperature reaches 4.63 × 10−5 S/cm, which is three orders of magnitude higher than the ionic conductivity of the simple PEO polymer, and maintains good cycle stability during the cycle of LiFePO4-based all-solid-state batteries [10]. Additionally, modifying PEO’s molecular structure, composition, and molecular weight through alkali polymerization (e.g., linear and comb-shaped PEO) also enhances its electrochemical properties. On the other hand, PEO faces challenges such as high softness, fabrication difficulties, poor mechanical stability, and instability under high pressure and temperature [61]. These issues can be addressed by incorporating plasticizers, although their effects on the electrochemical properties of electrolyte require careful evaluation. Alternatively, inorganic nanofillers or electrospinning methods can enhance mechanical performance while minimizing their impact on ionic conductivity by providing more efficient lithium-ion migration pathways. These modifications generally increase the crystallinity of PEO-based electrolytes, and when combined with lithium salts, can lead to high-performance solid electrolytes suitable for high-pressure applications. PVDF is another common polymer substrate that, in comparison to PEO, offers a higher dielectric constant (ε = 8.3), and a lower glass transition temperature T g (−35 °C). PVDF-based polymer electrolytes also exhibit a higher elastic modulus, which enhances their ability to suppress lithium dendrite growth and improves structural stability under high temperature and pressure. Nonetheless, PVDF has a lower solubility for lithium salts, a lack of active functional groups, and fewer donor sites for lithium coordination. In the presence of lithium metal anodes, PVDF can be unstable due to the possibility of fluorine groups reacting with lithium to form lithium fluoride (LiF) [62,63]. Dissolving suitable lithium salts in PVDF can still facilitate lithium-ion transport. The electron-withdrawing C–F groups in PVDF promote the dissociation of lithium salts. For instance, Liu et al. demonstrated that adding LiTFSI to PVDF polymer electrolytes achieved an ionic conductivity of 1.1 × 10−4 S/cm, a lithium ion transference number of 0.5, and a voltage stability window of 4 V [64]. Additionally, polymers such as polycarbonate (PC), including polycarbonate subethylene (PEC), polycarbonate subpropylene (PPC), polycarbonate subpropylene (PTMC), and polyacrylonitrile (PAN), also demonstrate good solubility for lithium salts and are utilized in the preparation of polymer electrolytes. Bertoli et al. developed a quasi-solid polymer electrolyte by uniformly blending polyoxyethylene and polycarbonate subpropylene, incorporating the plasticizer triethylene glycol dimethyl ether (TEGDME). This material exhibited an ionic conductivity of 8.32 × 10−5 S/cm at room temperature, an activation energy of 0.49 eV, and a stable voltage window exceeding 5 V [65]. 3.1.2 Oxide-based electrolytes Oxide-based solid electrolytes are a cornerstone of high-voltage solid-state batteries due to their outstanding electrochemical and thermal stability. Common SEs are characterized by fast-ion conductors, including perovskite, NASICON, LISICON, and garnet types. Despite room-temperature ionic conductivities typically ranging from 10−5 to 10−3 S/cm [66,67], their values are relatively low compared to liquid and sulfide electrolytes. This limits their charge-discharge rates and power densities, presenting a critical challenge for further development. Another critical issue with oxide electrolytes lies in their solid-solid interface contact with cathode and anode materials. Poor contact increases interfacial resistance and degrades performance. High-voltage operation further exacerbates this issue, intensifying interfacial side reactions and accelerating capacity decay. Strategies to improve oxide electrolytes vary depending on their structure. In perovskite-type Li3 x La2/3− x TiO3 (LLTO), optimizing elemental ratios has been effective. The ionic conductivity reaches a maximum of approximately 1 mS/cm when x is around 0.3, but decreases with higher lithium content. Grain boundary modification is another critical approach. Techniques such as introducing silicate boundary layers [68], optimizing elemental composition, and adjusting sintering temperatures have been employed to restructure grain boundaries [69]. Additionally, reducing Ti4+ to enhance electronic conductivity and prevent direct contact with the lithium metal anode has been explored, though the high cost of this approach limits LLTO broader application [70]. Na/Li super ionic conductors as high-voltage solid electrolytes are also constrained by low room-temperature ionic conductivity (10−7 S/cm). NASICON-type conductors typically follow the molecular formula L1+6 x M4+2− x M′3+ x (PO4)3 where M (Ti, Ge, Sn, Hf, or Zr) and M′ (Cr, Al, Ga, Sc, Y, In, or La) are substituted to optimize performance. The most common NASICON-type SEs include derivatives of LiTi2(PO4)3 and LiGe2(PO4)3, with Li1.3Al0.3Ti1.7(PO4)3 (LATP) and Li1.5Al0.5Ge1.5(PO4)3 (LAGP), both of which achieve room-temperature ionic conductivities between 10−4 and 10−3 S/cm under ambient conditions [71,72]. Similarly, LISICON conductors (with the formula Li3+ x Y x Z1− x O4）optimize ionic conductivity through element substitution and doping (e.g., Y = Si, Ge, Ti, Sc; Z = P, As, Cr, V, etc.) [73,74]. Moreover, analogous to LLTO-based high-voltage solid electrolytes, silicon-based oxide electrolytes are typically prepared in granular or powder forms. To mitigate interfacial resistance and improve contact at solid-solid interfaces, elevated temperatures or external pressure are frequently required. Garnet-type structured oxides Li7La3Zr2O12 (LLZO) demonstrates high stability toward lithium metal, rapid lithium-ion conductivity, and a broad electrochemical stability window. LLZO possesses two primary crystal structures: tetragonal and cubic. The tetragonal form exhibits limited stability, maintaining its structure only within a temperature range of 100–105 °C [75], with a corresponding ionic conductivity of approximately 10−7 S/cm [76]. In contrast, the cubic form of LLZO offers enhanced stability and ionic conductivity, exceeding the tetragonal phase by three orders of magnitude. Furthermore, doping strategies, including lithium vacancy engineering and the incorporation of elements like niobium and tantalum, have been shown to improve the stability and conductivity of the cubic phase further. Specifically, niobium doping can elevate the ionic conductivity of LLZNO to 7.0 × 10−4 S/cm [77], while tantalum doping can increase the ionic conductivity of LLZTO to 1.0 × 10−3 S/cm [78]. Although garnet-type SEs exhibit oxidation stability, their high Young's modulus poses challenges for effective contact with electrodes, typically necessitating high-temperature sintering to improve interface contact. However, high-temperature sintering inevitably results in the instability of the electrolyte and a decline in mechanical properties. To address this issue, a mechanical ball-milling method was employed to mix the garnet oxide LLZTO with LiBH4, yielding a novel composite electrolyte featuring an outer layer of Li4(BH4)3I and an inner layer of LiBO2. This composite was then cold-pressed at high pressure to ensure excellent mechanical strength and structural stability. As a result, the ionic conductivity of the composite was enhanced by three orders of magnitude compared to the original LLZTO. Furthermore, the composite was thoroughly mixed and ground with Li3BN2H8, a material known for its high ionic conductivity, at low temperatures [79,80]. After low-temperature heat treatment, a dense mixture of particles was obtained, exhibiting an ionic conductivity of 10−3 S/cm and an ionic mobility of 0.99 [81]. Notably, garnet-type SEs demonstrate favorable contact stability with lithium metal compared to other oxide types. 3.1.3 Sulfide electrolyte Sulfide electrolytes are recognized for their superior ion conduction and mechanical performance compared to oxide-type electrolytes. They establish robust solid-solid contact through cold pressing and exhibit excellent processing characteristics. The lower electronegativity and larger ionic radius of sulfide ions contribute to increased polarization and weaker Li–S bonds compared to Li–O bonds, resulting in more freely mobile lithium ions. Consequently, sulfide SEs demonstrate higher ionic conductivity at room temperature, typically ranging from 10−2 to 10−7 S/cm. As a result, these electrolytes are extensively utilized in solid-state battery research. Sulfide electrolytes can be primarily categorized into glass ceramic electrolytes, LGPS-type electrolytes, and Li6PS5X argyrodite electrolytes. Sulfide glass electrolytes are predominantly composed of Li2S and other sulfides, forming a poly-non-crystalline system. A noteworthy example is the Li2S-P2S5 glass electrolyte, which can transform into a glass-ceramic with significantly improved ionic conductivity through low-temperature thermal treatment. This transformation involves the precipitation of a metastable phase within the glass matrix, optimizing lithium-ion mobility. For the xLi2S-(100−x)P2S5 glass electrolyte, the ionic conductivity increases with increasing Li2S content, peaking at 2.1 × 10−4 S/cm when x reaches 80% [82,83]. A prominent sulfide solid electrolyte, Li10GeP2S12 (LGPS), boasts a room temperature ionic conductivity of up to 12 mS/cm to its distinctive tetragonal unit cell structure (P42/nmc). This framework, characterized by a three-dimensional framework composed of PS4 and [P/Ge]S4 tetrahedral units, enables efficient lithium ions distribute. However, the cost of germanium limits the practical applicability of LGPS. To reduce expenses, substituting germanium with main-group elements such as tin (Sn) or silicon (Si) can yield SEs with similar crystal structures. Modifications to LGPS-type crystal structures through chemical substitution enable the introduction of foreign elements, resulting in a series of fast lithium ion conductors, represented as Li10+ x M1+ x P2+ y S12− z A z (M = Si, Ge, Sn, Sb; A = O, Cl), which are structural analogues of LGPS [83]. The LPSX (sulfur-silver-germanium-type) high voltage SEs comprises both low-temperature and high-temperature phases. The high-temperature cubic phase exhibits high ionic conductivity, whereas Li7PS6 exists in a low-temperature orthorhombic phase at room temperature, characterized by low ionic conductivity. Halogen doping effectively stabilizes the high-temperature cubic phase (F4-3m space group) [84], enabling ionic conductivities up to 10−3–10−2 S/cm [85]. The ionic conductivity is intrinsically linked to anion positional disorder (S2−/X−), where increased positional disorder enhances ionic conductivity [86]. Under cold pressing conditions, the LPSX electrolyte achieves room-temperature ionic conductivities exceeding 10 mS/cm with low activation energy, affirming its potential as a highly promising high voltage SEs. Among its derivatives, the halogen-enriched LPSCl electrolyte combines cost-effectiveness, owing to the absence of precious metals, with a stable solid electrolyte interface (SEI) with lithium, underscoring its promise for application in all-solid-state lithium metal batteries. Nonetheless, sulfide-based high voltage SEs face several substantial challenges. They exhibit poor stability in air and react readily with moisture, producing hazardous hydrogen sulfide (H2S) gas. Additionally, their narrow electrochemical window (approximately 1.7–2.4 V) allows reduction by lithium metal, forming an ionically inert SEI predominantly consisting of Li2S and Li3P. The decomposition products accumulate at the interface between the sulfide solid electrolyte (SSE) and the lithium metal anode, increasing interface resistance and promoting uneven lithium deposition. Furthermore, sulfide SE decomposition yields ionically insulating by-products and electronically conductive lithium alloy composites (e.g., Li-Ge and Li-Sn alloys). The resulting mixed conductive interface (MCI) can facilitate direct electron transfer from the lithium metal anode to the sulfide SSE, resulting in continuous electrolyte decomposition and interface degradation. 3.1.4 Hydride-based electrolytes Hydride-based materials, traditionally known for their low ionic conductivity at room temperature (approximately 10−9 S/cm), have been primarily utilized as hydrogen storage media rather than solid-state electrolytes. However, recent studies have demonstrated that combined with mixed doping modifications, these materials can achieve satisfactory ionic conductivity at room temperature while maintaining a broad electrochemical stability window under high voltages. Among these, lithium borohydride (LiBH4) and magnesium borohydride (Mg(BH4)2) have emerged as promising candidates. Notably, LiBH4 has garnered significant attention as a solid electrolyte material with dual functionalities in hydrogen storage and ion conduction. LiBH4 exhibits thermodynamic stability when in contact with lithium metal anodes, which possesses a low molecular weight conducive to achieving high energy density and demonstrates good compressibility, which enhances compatibility at the solid-solid interface [86]. It also achieves a high lithium ion conductivity of 10−3 S/cm at elevated temperatures, specifically at 115 °C [87]. Nonetheless, its ionic conductivity at room temperature remains low (10−8 S/cm), and its oxidative stability (<2 V) and critical current density are limited. These limitations arise primarily from strong electrostatic interactions between Li+ and BH4 −, which restricts the mobility of Li+. Ionic conductivity can be enhanced through compositional modifications, such as synthesizing LiM(BH4)3N (M = La, Gd, Ce; N = Cl, Br, I) or introducing large molecules like NH3 or AB, which induce significant volumetric expansion in the LiBH4 structure. This process facilitates the formation of a one-dimensional Li ion diffusion pathway along the B-axis, characterized by a low activation energy barrier of 0.12 eV, which enhances the conductivity of Li ions [88]. Additionally, the introduction of substances such as Al2O3 or SiO2 creates a defect-rich interface layer [89], which increases the migration rate of Li+ through the space charge layer at room temperature, thereby raising the Li+ conductivity to 10−4 S/cm. Furthermore, partial substitution of BH4 − with halogen atoms further stabilizes the high-temperature phase of LiBH4 at ambient temperatures, while inert oxides promote faster Li+ conduction interfaces, significantly enhancing ionic conductivity. LiBH4 is hindered by its narrow electrochemical window and insufficient oxidative stability. The former can be addressed by synthesizing halogenated LiBH4 derivatives (LiBH4-LiCl-LiBr) [90] or polyhedral borohydrides ((Li2B12H11+1/ n ) n ), achieving a stable voltage window of 0 to 5 V [91]. The limited oxidative stability of LiBH4 arises from the poor thermodynamic stability of BH4−, whose localized electrons are prone to delocalization, leading to significant oxidative decomposition. This issue can be improved through anion engineering incorporating more stable halides, sulfides, or polyhedral borates to enhance the oxidative stability of LiBH4. Dendrite growth in hydride-based high voltage SEs is primarily driven by increased electronic conductivity at grain boundaries, attributed to a lower bandgap, which facilitates the reduction of mobile Li+ to lithium metal. A common approach to mitigate this issue involves introducing a secondary phase with low electronic conductivity (MgO or LiF) to form ionically or covalently bonded compounds (Li(AlO5BH4) or polyhedral borates) [92]. Furthermore, the enhancement of critical current density in hydrogen-based solid electrolytes has been extensively investigated, as demonstrated in recent work by Pan et al. [21]. Theoretical calculations of the Li-B-H phase diagram indicate that LiH is an oxidative decomposition product of LiBH4, exhibiting improved oxidative stability and superior reduction stability in relation to lithium compared to LiBH4. Through partial hydrogen release experiments conducted on prepared LiBH4, small amounts of LiH byproduct can be obtained, leading to an increase in ionic conductivity to 10−3 S/cm due to the synergistic effects of BH4− and B12H12 2−, and voltage window up to 6.0 V. Three different complexes, LiH, [Li2B12H11+1/ n ] n , and LiBH4, can be generated by hydrogen desorption at different temperatures at different times. The ultra-lithium ion mobility of the interface layer between [Li2B12H11+1/ n ] n and LiBH4 makes the ionic conductivity of the mixed electrolyte reach 2.7 × 10−4 S/cm at 35 °C, while maintaining good interface stability with the electrode, showing a voltage stability window of about 5 V [93]. By reducing the particle size of LiBH4, more transport paths can be provided for lithium-ion migration, and the co-deformation ability of electrolyte structure can be improved to improve the high voltage cycle stability. For example, porous SiO2 and LiBH4 are commonly mixed to achieve the size reduction of mixed particles, making the ionic conductivity of the composite material at 40 °C increased by three orders of magnitude [89]. In addition, Li2BH12H12 was introduced into polyvinylidene fluoride (vinylidene fluoride)-bis (trifluoromethanesulfonyl) imide lithium salt (PVDF-LiTFSI) combined with n-methylpyrrolidone plasticizer to prepare a new composite solid electrolyte with an ionic conductivity of 1.43 × 10−4 S/cm at 25 °C. After 200 cycles at 1 C and 25 °C, the assembled LiFePO4 battery has a reversible specific capacity of 140 mAh/g and a capacity retention rate of 98% [94]. As illustrated in Fig. 7 (a–c), first-principles calculations were conducted to determine the ionization and adsorption energies between LiBH4 and the polymer. The results indicate that PMMA, with an adsorption energy of 6.67 eV, exhibits a lower Li+ adsorption energy compared to LiBH4, which has an adsorption energy of 6.90 eV. This lower adsorption energy facilitates the migration and diffusion of Li+ ions. By employing cold pressing and hot-pressing techniques, a dense composite electrolyte material can be fabricated, which not only enhances ionic conductivity but also reduces electronic leakage and improves interface contact. Consequently, there is a significant improvement in ionic conductivity (Fig. 7d) and battery cycling performance at 0.5 C (Fig. 7e) [36,95]. These findings provide valuable insights for the advancement of hydrogen-based solid-state batteries. 3.1.5 Organic-inorganic composite electrolyte In summary, inorganic solid electrolytes have high mechanical strength and can achieve ionic conductivity comparable to liquid electrolytes through elemental doping and substitution [70]. However, non-ideal interface resistance remains a significant limitation for their practical applications [96]. In contrast, polymer electrolytes offer excellent interfacial compatibility owing to their lightweight, softness, and ease of manufacture properties. Nevertheless, they typically exhibit relatively low ionic conductivities (ranging from 10−6 to 10−9 S/cm) and offer minimal resistance to the growth of lithium dendrites formation [97]. It is apparent that neither purely inorganic nor purely organic solid electrolytes alone fully meet the requirements of high mechanical strength and favorable interface adhesion. As a result, focusing on organic-inorganic composite materials, where inorganic particles are efficiently integrated with polymer matrices, represents a promising strategy. Lanthanum lithium titanate oxide (LLTO), a typical perovskite oxide with a face-centered cubic structure, is widely employed as a solid electrolyte for lithium-ion batteries due to its high electrochemical stability and excellent room-temperature ionic conductivity. Fibrous inorganic filler polymer electrolytes demonstrate higher ionic conductivity characteristics than their granular counterparts. In these materials, fibrous or nanowire-structured fillers are uniformly blended within the polymer matrix, creating interconnected pathways that facilitate rapid lithium ion transmission (Fig. 8 a) [98]. For instance, LLZO nanofibers with an average diameter of approximately 400 nm can be added to a PVDF polymer, achieving a composition where LLTO nanofibers constitute 15 wt% of the outer layer of the electrolyte (referred to as LLTO-15), while LLTO nanofibers comprising 75 wt% of the inner layer structure (designated LLTO-75) (Fig. 8b) [99]. In this sandwich structure, LLTO-15 exhibits typical polymer characteristics, with a small quantity of ceramic fibers uniformly distributed throughout the PVDF polymer, forming a three-dimensional network matrix that is in direct contact with the upper and lower surfaces of both positive and negative electrodes, resulting in low interfacial resistance (Fig. 8c). Conversely, the LLTO-75 layer possesses typical ceramic characteristics, featuring a surface composed of densely packed fiber meshes integrated with PVDF polymer, which effectively inhibits lithium dendrite growth (Fig. 8d). However, the LLTO-45 configuration, which has a lower filler content than LLTO-75, fails to effectively suppress dendrite growth and continues to exhibit dendrite penetration (Fig. 8e). The fully assembled solid-state LiFePO4 battery, utilizing this sandwich solid electrolyte, demonstrates a high discharge specific capacity of 108 mAh/g at a rate of 1 C, retaining 91.7% of its capacity after 1000 cycles, with a corresponding coulombic efficiency exceeding 99.7% (Fig. 8f). These results indicate that the sandwich structure of the solid electrolyte electrode exhibits superior electrochemical performance, enhanced mechanical properties, good thermal stability, and excellent interface stability, along with superior compatibility with the electrode. 3.1.6 Multidimensional structural composite solid-state electrolyte For inorganic, organic, and composite SEs, specific advantages and disadvantages exist, making it challenging to achieve a comprehensive balance of electrochemical properties. This complexity complicates the construction of solid electrolyte materials that exhibit stable interfaces with lithium metal, high ionic conductivity, and robust interface bonding capabilities. A common approach to address these challenges involves blending and cross-linking various polymers [100], incorporating ceramic particles [101], reducing the crystallinity of polymers, and increasing their elastic modulus to effectively suppress lithium dendrite growth. Polypropylene carbonate (PPC), polyethylene oxide (PEO), and polyacrylonitrile (PAN) are frequently utilized as polymer electrolyte materials. However, these materials tend to oxidize at Li/Li+ potentials exceeding 3.9 V. The decomposition products of these polymers can exhibit a degree of lithium-ion conductivity, leading to the formation of a relatively stable cathode electrolyte interface (CEI) layer. This interface layer is crucial for maintaining the stability of both the cathode and the solid electrolyte during prolonged cycling of the battery. Nevertheless, for layered cathode materials such as LiCoO2, the strong oxidizing ability during high-voltage cycling can accelerate the decomposition of the polymer electrolyte, resulting in gas evolution from LiCoO2 and initiating a detrimental cycle of cumulative reactions. This process contributes to the continuous growth of the electrochemical interface between the electrolyte and the cathode material, ultimately compromising the structural integrity of the cathode and leading to significant declines in cycling performance [102]. Lu et al. developed a three-dimensional (3D) composite electrolyte using a PVDF-HFP-LLZO-PPC structure to achieve long-term high-energy-density battery cycling. The PPC layer is designed to degrade controllably, addressing the poor solid-solid interface contact and establishing a stable interface with the lithium metal. The interconnected structure of 3D-LLZO facilitates rapid ionic conductivity, ensuring adequate mechanical strength for the electrolyte while concurrently reducing polymer crystallinity. The strong antioxidant properties of PVDF-HFP enhance compatibility with high-voltage positive electrode materials, effectively preventing redox reactions between PPC and the positive electrode [103]. Additionally, poly(vinylidene fluoride-hexafluoropropylene) (PVDF-HFP) serves as the polymer electrolyte in contact with the lithium metal negative electrode due to its high modulus and intrinsic hardness. Upon contact with lithium metal, PVDF-HFP reacts to form a LiF layer, which effectively inhibits the growth of lithium dendrites. Furthermore, the polyacrylonitrile (PAN) antioxidant layer enhances the stability of the contact between the electrolyte and the cathode, while the polypropylene (PP) film acts as both a structural framework and a connecting layer within the electrolyte, thereby improving ionic diffusion and mechanical strength. The three-dimensional “hamburger” structure of composite PVDF-HFP-PP-PAN significantly ameliorates interface issues between the solid electrolyte and electrode materials [16]. 3.2 Interface engineering In order to reflect the advantages of the energy density of all-solid-state batteries, ASSLBs usually uses high-voltage materials as the cathode, but the interface between the solid electrolyte and the electrode has consistently been a critical factor influencing the electrochemical performance of solid-state batteries. The first is the chemical instability of the interface between the solid electrolyte and the electrode. Due to the difference in chemical potentials, the sulfide electrolyte produces a high impedance reaction layer at the interface when it is in contact with the positive electrode, hindering the Li+ transport, and the oxides have a better chemical stability in comparison, but the higher modulus of elasticity makes the solid-solid interface not very good contact, resulting in the increased interface resistance. It usually needs to be used after treatment at high temperature, and the side reactions of element diffusion and interface decomposition under high voltage will also lead to the deterioration of battery performance. The second is the electrochemical instability between the cathode and the electrolyte, such as the PEO-based polymer electrolyte, due to its strong oxidation leading to a narrow voltage window and quickly reacting with the cathode under high voltage conditions. The third is the problem of poor solid-solid interface contact between the electrolyte and the electrode. In the process of charge and discharge cycle, the negative electrode will undergo volume changes, leading to the interface contact problem between the electrolyte and the gap and defect, which further promotes the growth of lithium dendrites, and the composite positive electrode causes the structure to break because of the delinking and migration of lithium ions [104]. Addressing this issue is essential for maximizing the advantages of solid-state batteries and minimizing solid-solid interface resistance. Consequently, research on the electrolyte/electrode interface has emerged as a major focus within the field of solid-state batteries. Various methods have been employed to mitigate this issue, including chemical composition regulation [105], the application of external pressure or thermal treatment [106], surface roughening [107], and interface modification [108]. Sulfide, one of the most promising solid electrolytes, has attracted the attention of most researchers, and a series of studies have been done on the chemical stability of sulfide. (1−x)Li3PS4·2xLiBH4 mixed solid electrolyte was prepared by ball milling of Li3PS4 and LiBH4. Due to the addition of LiBH4, which has good thermal stability, the electrolyte can maintain good interface compatibility with the lithium metal anode, and the ionic conductivity can reach 11 mS/cm [109]. When Li3PS4 is mixed with LiBH4 and LiBr, the number of PS3−, BH−, and Br− anion units in the electrolyte can further improve the chemical stability and ionic conductivity of the electrolyte. The ionic conductivity of Li3PS4·1.8LiBH4·0.7LiBr electrolyte at room temperature is 14.4 mS/cm [110]. Oxide solid electrolytes have better chemical stability than sulfide solid electrolytes, but their higher modulus of elasticity can easily lead to incomplete contact interfaces with electrodes, and the formation of high interfacial resistance makes the battery performance drop sharply. The oxide solid electrolyte is usually sintered at high temperatures (>500 °C) to enhance the structural densities, improve the contact problems with the electrode interface, and form an ion diffusion layer at the cathode, which plays the role of blocking electrons. For example, the addition of small-scale La2O3 and Li6.5La3Zr1.5Ta0.5O12 (LLZTO) particles in the common mixed sintering, as the second phase, inhibits the abnormal growth of LLZTO particles, while reducing defects such as pores, improving electrolyte density, solving the contact problem, and inhibiting the growth of lithium dendrites, and the battery cycle stability has been greatly improved [111]. Among these approaches, interface modification stands out as a particularly effective strategy for mitigating interfacial resistance in high voltage solid-state batteries. One effective method involves introducing a buffer layer that reacts with lithium metal to form a stable metal compound. This layer not only prevents undesirable side reactions between the solid electrolyte and the lithium metal anode, but also functions as a binder to enhance the adhesion, significantly reducing interface resistance. For instance, employing an amorphous silicon (Si) buffer layer on garnet-type solid electrolytes lowers the interfacial resistance from 925 to 127 Ω/cm2. Similar phenomena have been observed in graphite, ZnO, Ge and Al2O3, which have the effect of drastically reducing the interfacial resistance. However, the preparation of lithium metal buffer layers often requires treatment at high temperatures (exceeding 200 °C) to achieve optimal bonding between the lithium metal, the buffer layer, and the solid electrolyte. Unfortunately, elevated treatment temperatures can accelerate reactions involving lithium metal, leading to oxidation and mechanical degradation of the garnet-type solid electrolyte, which significantly compromises the electrochemical performance of the battery [112]. Sulfides present a promising alternative, as they can react with lithium metal at lower temperatures (2Li + xS → Li2S x , 2 < x < 8). They can be employed as “reactants” to enhance the interfacial reaction between lithium metal and the garnet electrolyte [113]. As illustrated in Fig. 9 (c), sulfur and its lithiated products exhibit low ionic conductivity (5 × 10−30 S/cm) but possess favorable interface adhesion properties; hence, the sulfur coating on the lithium metal surface requires careful control. A spraying method can be utilized to uniformly distribute a sulfur solution as a mist over the surface of garnet-type electrolyte particles. The thickness of the sulfur coating can be adjusted by regulating the spraying time to approximately 50–80 nm (Fig. 9a, b). When heated to 130 °C, the sulfur transforms into a molten state and reacts to generate a black, sticky Li2S x product (Fig. 9c), which acts as a protective layer and an interface “welding” agent. This treatment temperature is significantly lower than the melting point of lithium metal (180.5 °C), thereby minimizing the likelihood of unwanted side reactions at the interface. To further investigate the beneficial effects of sulfides at the interface, two symmetrical cells were assembled: Li/garnet electrolyte/Li and Li/S-garnet electrolyte-S/Li, and subjected to electrochemical performance testing. The Nyquist plot revealed significant differences in the total resistance of the two cells. As shown in Fig. 9(d), the total resistance of the Li/garnet electrolyte/Li symmetrical cell was 2200 Ω/cm2, with an interface resistance of approximately 1750 Ω/cm2. In contrast, the Li/S-garnet electrolyte-S/Li symmetrical cell exhibited a total resistance of 610 Ω/cm2, with the interface resistance being reduced to approximately 160 Ω/cm2. Thus, the interface resistance following sulfur coating was reduced by more than an order of magnitude. 4 Prospects for the future To achieve higher energy densities, advancing the development of solid-state batteries capable of operating at elevated voltages is essential. High-voltage solid-state batteries, as the next generation of battery technology, offer significant advantages, including increased energy density, enhanced safety, and extended cycle life. Solid-state electrolyte is the most important part of all-solid-state battery system, of which electrochemical characteristics directly affect the overall performance of the battery, so the development of high-voltage solid-state electrolyte determines the development of solid-state battery to a new height. Effective solid electrolytes must meet several key requirements: high ionic conductivity, low ionic area-specific resistance, high electronic area-specific resistance, excellent ion selectivity, a broad electrochemical stability window, good chemical compatibility with other components, outstanding thermal stability, superior mechanical properties, a straightforward manufacturing process, low cost, ease of device integration, and environmental sustainability. In addition, the electrode material and the interface contact between the electrode and the solid electrolyte also play a pivotal role in the overall structure of the battery. The direct combination of a solid electrolyte with the highest ionic conductivity and a high-performance electrode does not necessarily lead to a high-performance battery, so in the forefront of the continuous development of high-pressure solid electrolytes, electrode and interface issues in all-solid-state batteries will also follow. With technological advancements and the growing demand for high-performance batteries, the prospects for high-voltage solid-state batteries are highly promising. Below are several key directions for future research and development. 4.1 The research and development of novel electrolytes The design of high-voltage solid electrolytes must carefully balance the thickness and weight of the material. Achieving high energy density and voltage resistance requires maintaining a thin and lightweight electrolyte without compromising its mechanical strength. Certain solid electrolytes with high ionic conductivity face challenges in interface contact with the electrodes, while others demonstrate the opposite characteristics. Composite structures offer a viable solution by mitigating the limitations of individual components and leveraging their advantages. They address physical and chemical interface issues with the cathode, providing better insight into and optimization of the functionality of full-cell solid electrolytes [114]. Currently, high-voltage solid electrolytes can be broadly categorized into oxide, polymer, and sulfide SEs. Sulfide SEs demonstrate ionic conductivities comparable to those of liquid electrolytes, typically ranging from 10−2 to 10−3 S/cm. However, a significant challenge associated with sulfide-containing SEs is their poor stability in air, necessitating that production be conducted in a glove box filled with inert gas. This requirement complicates production and increases costs. The decomposition mechanisms of solid electrolytes in the presence of air have been analyzed using the hard-soft acid-base (HSAB) theory [115]. The central cation, P5+, acts as a hard acid that preferentially forms P–O bonds with hard bases such as O2− present in air or water, rather than with the softer base S2−. Concurrently, S2− tends to react with hydrogen in the environment, generating toxic hydrogen sulfide H2S gas and reducing ionic conductivity. Based on HSAB theory, researchers have proposed several strategies to enhance the air stability of solid electrolyte materials. A particularly effective approach involves co-doping with metal oxides, which not only improves the air stability of solid electrolytes but also enhances their ionic conductivity [116,117]. For instance, a novel Li3+3 x P1− x Zn x S4− x O x electrolyte was synthesized by incorporating ZnO into Li3PS4. In this system, Zn2+ partially substitutes P5+, while O2− partially replaces S2−, thereby inhibiting the reaction between the electrolyte and moisture and enhancing air stability [118]. This doping strategy increased the ionic conductivity of the solid electrolyte to 1.12 × 10−3 S/cm, effectively doubling the original conductivity. Additionally, Li3PS4 co-doped with Bi2O3 to form Li3+2 x P1− x Bi x S4−1.5 x O1.5 x single-electron materials. The co-doping of Bi and O modified the bonds and structure of Li3PS4, with Bi3+ partially substituted by P5+ and O2− partially replaced by S2−. Other metal oxides, such as P2O5 and Sb2O5, have also been introduced into SEs to improve their air stability. For sulfide solid electrolyte before modification, its stability in the air is extremely poor, and the oxidation decomposition of sulfide will inevitably be accelerated under high voltage conditions, and the structural collapse will lead to a significant reduction in ionic conductivity. This oxide doping method improves the structural stability and ionic conductivity of sulfide solid electrolyte under high voltage. It has good interface stability with lithium metal anode, and the battery cycle stability has been greatly improved [33]. Replacing soft acid atoms, such as substituting P with Sn, is another common strategy to improve the air stability of sulfide electrolytes. Sn, being a milder acid than P, demonstrates greater stability when combined with the soft base S, thereby enhancing the air stability of the sulfide electrolytes. For lithium-ion conducting oxide SEs like LLZO, the substitution of metal atoms can further augment ionic conductivity. For example, substituting Zr4+ with tetravalent metal ions stabilizes the cubic structure of Li7La3Zr2O12 (LLZO), achieving an ionic conductivity of 10−4 S/cm at room temperature [119]. Partial replacement of Zr by Ta generated Li7− x La3Zr2− x Ta x O2 electrolytes, with ionic conductivities reaching 1.0 × 10−3 S/cm and an activation energy of approximately 0.35 eV [20]. In addition to Ta doping, other high-valent metals such as Sb5+, Nb5+, Te6+, and W6+ can also be utilized to replace Zr4+. Notably, Nb doping is particularly common in LLZO (LLZNO), with optimal doping levels around 0.4 or 0.5. For example, Wen et al. synthesized 0.4Nb-LLZO, achieving an ionic conductivity of 6.0 × 10−4 S/cm [76], while Zhang et al. synthesized 0.5Nb-LLZO with an ionic conductivity of 7.0 × 10−4 S/cm [120]. In garnet-type SEs, LLZNO and LLZTO have been investigated more extensively. Despite their exceptional oxidation resistance, garnet-type SEs face substantial obstacles when applied to high-voltage oxide cathodes. The primary challenge lies in their high elastic modulus, which often requires high-temperature sintering to ensure effective contact with electrode powders. Although the sulfide solid electrolyte has good chemical stability, the point-to-point interface contact caused by its high elastic modulus makes the battery have a large interface resistance. At high voltage, the transmission of lithium ions is bound to be greatly hindered, and the reaction with the electrode generates a bad interface layer, which aggravates the structural decomposition of the oxide electrolyte material. To mitigate these issues, garnet SEs can be integrated with polymers, improving interfacial adhesion and overall compatibility. In particular, inorganic ceramic SE particles, known for their high ionic conductivity, hold significant potential for advancing the performance of composite solid-state electrolytes. However, the interface contact with the electrode remains a major drawback. Conversely, polymer-based SEs generally have slightly lower ionic conductivity and weaker mechanical strength. Composite SEs combine the advantages of both inorganic and polymer materials, fulfilling the physical and chemical requirements of solid-state batteries. By adopting new preparation processes or developing novel high-performance electrolyte materials, unexpected enhancements can be realized. For instance, the development of a CD-Si cyclodextrin three-dimensional framework combined with PVDF and PEO to create film-like electrolytes has significantly suppressed lithium dendrite growth, achieving an impressive ionic conductivity of 2.4 × 10 −3 S/cm [121]. Modifications through elemental doping can alter the internal structure of electrolyte materials and further enhance their electrochemical performance. However, such improvements are often limited and insufficient for continuous cycling under high-voltage conditions. The nanostructured electrolyte design is also considered to be an effective way to improve the electrochemical and mechanical properties of the solid electrolyte, improve the transfer rate of lithium ion in electrolyte under high voltage, and improve the co-deformation ability of electrolyte material and electrode material. Nanostructured SEs in the form of nanoparticles, nanorods, or nanofibers exhibit high surface area and high active surface sites, and these nanostructured solid electrolytes offer different ion transport mechanisms when hybridized with polymers and lithium salts compared to the bulk structure of solid electrolytes. The integration of solid components into polymers has been demonstrated in a range of materials, including nanoparticles, nanofibers, and others. In composite systems, the addition of nanoparticles affects the recrystallization kinetics of PEO polymer chains, promotes the formation of local amorphous regions, and improves the ionic conductivity of Li salt/polymer system [122,123]. 4.2 Innovations of electrode materials The electrochemical performance of solid-state batteries hinges on the seamless synergy between positive and negative electrode materials and the solid electrolyte. While continuous optimization of the electrolyte material and structure can enhance battery performance, achieving higher energy density necessitates ongoing research and exploration of electrode materials. High voltage cathode materials mainly include spinel structure LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4 (LNMO), layered structure LiCoO2, ternary cathode material Li(Ni, Co, Mn/Al)O2, Li-rich manganese based cathode materials LiMn2O3LiMO2 (M = Co/Mn/Ni), LiFePO4, olivine structure LiCoPO4 and LiNiPO4, etc., which are different from solid electrolyte requirements, as a positive electrode material for solid state batteries. Good ionic and electronic conductivity is required, while the ionic conductivity of conventional cathode active materials is low (∼10−7–10−9 S/cm), and in order to meet the demand for high-voltage operation, composite electrode structures are usually prepared by mixing with an appropriate amount of solid electrolyte. In order to obtain a high energy density and ensure the electronic seepage of the components, the volume fraction of the solid electrolyte in the electrode should not exceed 50% at most, and the lower solid electrolyte content reduces the further transmission of the ionic conductivity in the composite electrode, so the volume proportion should not be less than 25% to maintain a high voltage normal ion/electron transport. The energy density of the battery is improved [124]. Taking NCM811 cathode material as an example, it is calculated that if the solid state battery composed of NCM811 and LPS sulfide wants to have good electrochemical performance, the ion conductivity transmission is hindered when the active substance: electrolyte (vol%) > 79:21 in the composite positive electrode, and when the electron conductivity is reduced when the active substance: electrolyte (vol%) < 69:31, the transmission is inhibited, and the specific column addition is slightly different for different positive and electrolyte materials [125]. For composite anode materials, the ionic/electronic conductivity is not only related to the amount of active substance and electrolyte added to the electrode, but the particle size of the substance also has a large influence. Smaller particle size can further increase the specific surface area of contact between living substances and electrolytes, resulting in higher effective ionic conductivity. The smaller the particle size, the larger the specific surface area. The electrolyte content required to be added to the composite anode material will also be relatively reduced. At the same time, the smaller particle size in the electrode can avoid the gaps and holes caused by incomplete contact between the particles, which hinder the transmission of ions/electrons, improve the cycle stability of the electrode sheet under high voltage, and improve the cycle performance of the battery. Researchers have conducted extensive studies aimed at developing positive electrode materials with greater energy densities, optimizing the stoichiometry of chemical elements, and implementing element doping or surface coating techniques. Lithium iron phosphate (LiFePO4, LFP) is a prominent cathode material in lithium-ion batteries, recognized for its stable rutile-like structure, cost-effectiveness, and ease of fabrication. Despite these merits, its intrinsic limitations, including low energy density and restricted ionic conductivity (approximately 10−10–10−9 S/cm), fails to meet the increasing demand for battery power density. In contrast, layered oxides with high lithium content represent some of the most promising positive electrode materials, featuring low manufacturing costs, a high voltage window (up to 5.2 V), and substantial charge and discharge specific capacities. The presence of excess lithium ions is essential for achieving high specific capacities in layered oxides. However, high levels of lithium extraction and utilization can lead to structural collapse of the layered oxide, resulting in capacity reduction and diminished cycle performance. Among the transition metals (TM, Mn, Co, and Ni), nickel is particularly notable for its relatively low ionization barrier, which allows it to behave similarly to Li+ [126]. In an appropriate lithium-deficient state, nickel ions can stabilize the crystal structure, and the in situ formation of a spinel coating can protect the cathode material from electrolyte erosion while inhibiting the release of surface lattice oxygen [55]. Lithium-rich and manganese-rich layered oxides (LMRO) can achieve energy densities of up to 1000 Wh/kg. In this configuration, nickel enhances the battery capacity and cobalt stabilizes the material structure and improves cycle life, while manganese contributes to safety and thermal stability. However, LMROs typically exhibit low initial capacity and experience rapid capacity degradation due to the reconfiguration of lithium and manganese ions during cycling [127]. The ionic radii of Ni2+ are similar to those of Li+, allowing Ni2+ to occupy Li+ sites in the lithium layer, a phenomenon known as cation mixing.
