An appropriate increase in nickel content can support the lithium layer and reduce the repulsive forces between adjacent oxygen layers, thereby enhancing the structural stability of the LMRO positive electrode material [128]. The Ni4+/Ni2+ ratio demonstrates a higher reduction potential compared to the Co4+/Co3+ and Mn4+/Mn3+ phases, which can further elevate the working voltage of the LMRO electrode material [129]. The properties of electrode materials are closely linked to their chemical composition; even slight variations in element content can induce significant structural changes and, consequently, affect performance. Furthermore, the doping of additional elements and surface coatings can exert specific influences on the structure and performance of the cathode material. Doping with elements such as Nb, P, Sr, Sc, and V can modify the crystal structure of LMRO and regulate the redox activity of anions during cycling, thereby reducing irreversible oxygen evolution and stabilizing lattice oxygen, which enhances cycling stability. Surface coatings can create a uniform and thin layer of fast lithium ion conductor [58], impeding electrolyte penetration and promoting the formation of a spinel phase on the outer layer of the particles. This mechanism accelerates lithium ion diffusion kinetics and suppresses structural transformations from the surface to the interior of the particles, thereby ensuring the stability of the layered structure during battery cycling [57]. For example, Cheng et al. adopted Li3BO3, a substance that is mechanically soft and conductive, to uniformly coat the LiCoO2 cathode material with a layer. Employing an aerosol deposition (AD) method, a composite cathode layer with a thickness of 4.3 μm was fabricated on the surface of an aluminum-doped LLZO solid electrolyte. After being subjected to heat treatment at 750 °C for 1 h, Li3BO3 melts during the heating process and acts as an adhesive to fill the voids of the interface between the LiCoO2 cathode material and the LLZO solid electrolyte, achieving a synergistic optimization of the cathode material and the interface resistance [130]. 4.3 Optimization of the interface Interface instability remains a significant bottleneck in the development of ASSBs. Inadequate point-to-point contact between the SE and electrode materials exacerbates interfacial resistance while triggering undesirable reactions between SEs and lithium metal anodes. This instability promotes uneven lithium deposition, as depicted in Fig. 10 (a and b), where irregular interface contacts result in a non-uniform lithium layer. These irregularities create localized hot spots that accelerate lithium dendrite growth. Moreover, the formation of a mixed conductive interface can lead to electron leakage and heighten interface resistance, progressively deteriorating the electrolyte structure. To mitigate these issues, various strategies have been employed to establish stable interfaces between lithium and the electrolyte, including enhancements of the electrolyte composition, the development of alloyed anodes, and the creation of artificial interfaces (Fig. 10c). For instance, halogen elements (such as F, Cl, Br, and I) can be doped into SEs to synthesize high-purity nanocrystals. This doping can improve the electrochemical stability of sulfide-based SEs and facilitate the formation of a SEI enriched with halide ions characterized by high interface energy. However, it is important to note that element doping often results in reduced overall ionic conductivity of the solid electrolyte, which is typically addressed by incorporating materials with higher ionic conductivity [131]. The preparation of alloyed anode materials also presents an effective solution to the interface challenges associated with SEs. Lithium-rich alloys, such as Li-In, Li-Al, and Li-Ag alloys, exhibit the enhanced electrode potentials and improved lithium-ion kinetics, making them widely utilized in sulfide-based lithium-ion ASSBs. These alloys can effectively minimize the decomposition of sulfide SEs and inhibit the growth of lithium dendrites. Nonetheless, the use of lithium alloy anodes can lead to a decrease in the operating voltage of the battery, thereby compromising overall energy density. Consequently, artificial interface protective layers have emerged as a transformative solution. Acting as “adhesives”, these layers strengthen the bond between SEs and electrode materials, significantly reducing interface resistance. Simultaneously, they prevent side reactions without substantially affecting energy density, making them integral to improving the overall performance of ASSBs. The high voltage cycle stability of all-solid-state batteries is not only related to the electrochemical characteristics of the electrodes and electrolyte materials, but also closely related to the internal interface of the battery. The interface problem has been improved by the method of external interface layer, and some researchers have also found that the external stress of solid-state batteries has the same improvement effect on the interface problem of solid-state batteries. It plays an important role in the structural stability of the battery cycle under high voltage. In a wide range of solid electrolytes, it is generally observed that the growth of fine lithium wire due to the uneven deposition of lithium ions is mainly distributed in the grain boundaries, holes, and defect sites of solid electrolytes. Under the condition of high voltage, the uneven contact of the interface leads to the blockage of lithium-ion transmission, local overheating, lithium metal preferential nucleation at the grain boundaries and void, and the current density is concentrated at the hot spot, resulting in highly localized pressure and overpotential, and the molar volume of lithium metal is about 10 times higher than that of inorganic solid electrolyte. It causes extreme local expansion and puts the solid electrolyte under stress, prompting the electrolyte to first produce micro-cracks at the edge and gradually expand to the center; the cracks propagate through the grains, grain boundaries, and voids; and lithium is deposited inside, eventually leading to the electrolyte structure cracking and the battery short circuiting [132]. Some studies have found that for halide LPSX (X = Cl, Br, I) solid electrolyte, with the increase of applied stress, the electrolyte surface becomes smoother, and the corresponding specific surface area in contact with the electrode also increases relatively. With the application of appropriate pile stress, the overall structure of the electrolyte becomes denser, and the relative density of the electrolyte reaches 67% at 5 MPa. When the pressure increases to 100 MPa, the relative density reaches 79%, but too much pressure leads to a rapid short circuit of the battery, and appropriate applied stress (30–50 MPa) not only reduces the interface resistance, but also increases the specific capacity of the battery cycle; at the same time, lithium dendrites grow under high voltage, making the battery cycle stability greatly improved [133]. In addition, nanosized particles, which has recently attracted much attention from researchers, also has a significant effect on improving the high-pressure interface. The nano control of electrode materials and electrolyte particles has greatly improved the interface contact problem, and the nano electrolyte particles also mean the increase of the degree of electrolyte disorder, providing more migration directions and migration channels for the migration of lithium ions, improving the deformation ability of the electrode volume change under high voltage, and increasing the stability of the battery cycle [134,135]. The nanoization of battery materials realizes the joint improvement of dynamics and thermodynamics, and is one of the main directions for the development of high-voltage all-solid-state batteries in the future. Soc. 144 (2022) 9597-9609. Zhijun Wu received his MS degree from the Taiyuan University of Technology in 2017, and received his PhD degree from the Hirosaki University in 2020. He is currently a lecturer at Xi’an Technological University. His main research focuses on Li-rich cathode materials for LIBs and solid state batteries. Hao Tian was born in Henan, China, in 1997. He received his M.S. degree in Materials and Chemical Engineering from Xi'an Technological University in 2020. After graduation, he started his Ph.D. study under the supervision of Prof. Hongge Pan. His research is focused on All-solid-state batteries. Dali Ji joined The UNSW Team Graphene and received his Ph.D. in Materials Science and Engineering in 2024. Then he continued his research in UNSW and was elected as member of Royal Australian Chemical Institute. Then he moved to Zhejiang Key Laboratory of Advanced Solid State Energy Storage Technology and Applications, Zhejiang University as principal investigator. His research focuses on the design and development of 2D electrochemical materials for clean energy, with expertise in advanced membranes, hydrogen production and solid-state electrolytes. Xin Zhang was born in Henan, China, in 1987. He received his Ph.D. in Materials Science and Engineering from Zhejiang University in 2016. Now, he continues his research in Zhejiang University as a associate researcher. His research expertise includes solid-state hydrogen storage materials and solid state electrolyte materials. Lanxun Li was born in 1999 in Jiangxi, China. He received his Bachelor's degree in Materials Science and Engineering from Tianjin University of Technology in 2022. After graduation, he began his Ph.D. study under the guidance of Professor Yongfeng Liu. His research focused on solid-state electrolyte materials for lithium-ion batteries. Zichen Lou was born in Jiangsu, China, in 2000. She received her B.C. degree in Materials Science and Engineering from China University of Mining and Technology in 2022. After graduation, she started her Ph.D. study under the supervision of Prof. Yongfeng Liu. Her research is focused on solid-state hydrogen storage materials Wenping Sun received his B.S. degree in 2008 and Ph.D. degree in 2013 in Materials Science and Engineering from the University of Science and Technology of China (USTC). He is currently a professor at School of Materials Science and Engineering, Zhejiang University. His research expertise includes electro-catalysis, fuel cells, and batteries, especially the design of novel materials and structures, and fundamental understandings of related electrochemical processes. Mingxia Gao received her Ph.D. in Materials Science and Engineering from Zhejiang University in 2004. She is currently a professor at Zhejiang University. Her research is focused on solid-state hydrogen storage materials and lithium-ion batteries. Yongfeng Liu received his Ph.D. in Materials Science and Engineering from Zhejiang University in 2005. He then moved to the National University of Singapore as a postdoctoral research fellow (working with Dr. Ping Chen). In 2007, he joined Zhejiang University as an Associate Professor. In 2012, he became a Professor in Materials Science and Engineering at Zhejiang University. He is a winner of the National Natural Science Foundation for Excellent Youth Scholars of China (2012). His research is focused on solid-state hydrogen storage materials and electrode materials of rechargeable batteries. Hongge Pan received his Ph.D. in Materials Science and Engineering from Zhejiang University in 1996 under a joint program between Zhejiang University and the Institute of Physics, Chinese Academy of Science. Later that year, he joined Zhejiang University and was promoted to an Associate Professor in 1997. In 1999, He became a Professor in Materials Science and Engineering at Zhejiang University. He won the National Natural Science Foundation for Distinguished Young Scholars of China (2010). His research is focused on energy materials for solid-state hydrogen storage and lithium-ion batteries.

coredata.dc:description: Solid-state batteries (SSBs) are highly attractive on account of their high energy density and good safety. In high-voltage and high-current conditions, however, the interface reactions, structural changes, and decomposition of the electrolyte impede the transmission of lithium ions in all-solid-state lithium batteries (ASSLBs), significantly reducing the charging and discharging capacity and cycling stability of the battery and therefore restricting its practical applications. The main content of review is to conduct an in-depth analysis of the existing problems of solid-state batteries from the aspects of interface reactions, material failure, ion migration, and dendrite growth, and points out the main factors influencing the electrochemical performance of ASSLBs. Additionally, the compatibility and ion conduction mechanisms between polymer electrolytes, inorganic solid electrolytes, and composite electrolytes and the electrode materials are discussed. Furthermore, the perspectives of electrode materials, electrolyte properties, and interface modification are summarized and prospected, providing new optimization directions for the future commercialization of high-voltage solid-state electrolytes.
